subject: Art & Design
title: Anatomy of a Letter: Baseline to Ascender
description: A fast breakdown of Anatomy of a Letter: Baseline to Ascender for builders.

hook.text: Every letter sits on an invisible line. Type designers call it the baseline.

buildup.text: The x-height is how tall lowercase letters like 'a' and 'e' are. It affects perceived size hugely.

discovery.text: Ascenders (like 'h' and 'l') reach up. Descenders (like 'g' and 'p') hang below the baseline.

twist.text: Two fonts at the same point size can look completely different sizes if their x-heights differ.

climax.text: Designers pick fonts with large x-heights for screens because they're more readable at small sizes.

punchline.text: Point size is a lie. X-height is the truth.

quiz.question: Why do fonts with larger x-heights work better on screens?
options: They appear more readable at small sizes
Screens can only render tall letters
